Award.AwardTitle: SG: Preference by birds for rare species of fruits and its role in maintaining diversity in plant communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to better understand the process of fruit-selection in birds, and in turn, how fruit-selection affects the diversity and composition of plant communities. The vast majority of woody plant species - especially in the most diverse forests - depend on fruit-eating birds to disperse their seeds, but information on the factors governing fruit choice and seed dispersal at a community level is lacking. This project will address this shortcoming through observations and experiments across the Americas. The overarching goal of the research is to test the hypothesis that fruit-eating birds of different sizes and classes increase dispersal rates for plant species that are proportionally rare in the environment. Achieving a better understanding of seed dispersal by birds is critically important to advancing ecology, since plant populations depend on seed dispersal to regenerate, coexist, colonize new areas, shift geographic ranges, and cope with climatic and other environmental changes. Beyond advancing basic science, the knowledge generated by this research will have positive implications for forestry, natural resource management, restoration ecology, and conservation. The activities will result in the training of graduate and undergraduate students, and broaden the education and participation of minorities in the sciences while fostering international collaboration and exchanges between researchers and students from the USA, Peru, and Argentina.

Existing theory and empirical work suggest that equalizing and stabilizing mechanisms involving negative density-dependence (NDD) play key roles in the maintenance of species diversity by conferring advantages to species that are relatively rare in communities. This project will study a little known class of NDD process that, if proven to be of widespread occurrence, can be important for diversity maintenance and the structuring of plant-frugivore mutualistic communities: antiapostatic frugivory and seed dispersal. Antiapostatic frugivory would result in disproportionately high seed dispersal when species' fruits are relatively rare in communities of plants that share frugivorous seed dispersal agents such as birds. To examine the generality of antiapostatic frugivory, this research will conduct field studies in four continental localities representing four distinct plant-frugivore communities. These communities provide fully independent biotic and abiotic elements in which to test occurrence and magnitude of antiapostatic frugivory as they are located across a latitudinal gradient: from eastern North America (Pennsylvania) to southern South America (Patagonia), including two Peruvian forest sites (lowland Amazonian rainforest at Madre de Dios, and an Andean cloud forest at Abra Patricia). In addition to observations of fruit consumption and plant demography, controlled fruit-selection experiments using natural and artificial fruit displays will be conducted.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we studied six plant-bird communities spanning latitudes, elevations, and humidity regimes in Pennsylvania (1 site), Puerto Rico (1 site), Peru (2 sites), Brasil (1 site), and Argentina (1 site). In each study site we established a plot measuring 1.0-1.6 hectares that was subdivided in 10 x 10 m cells where we collected spatially-explicit fruit availability of bird-dispersed plant species measured in a weekly manner and the concomitant fruit-eating patterns of the avian communities. We recorded detailed information on how individuals of 128 species of birds moved within the study areas and responded to habitat structural features and the abundance and fruit traits of a total of 134 plant species. The main objective of collecting these data was to evaluate how the foraging behavior of avian seed dispersers contributes to the maintenance of plant species diversity in natural communities. The specific hypothesis we investigated was that bird foraging for fruit resources follows and anti-apostatic (rare-bias) functional response, resulting in equalizing effects on the seed rain. We found that in four out of the six communities, > 75% of bird species showed rare-biased functional responses. We also found no relationship between bird phylogeny and the probability of rare-biased frugivory in bird species, showing that this is a general mechanism that can contribute to the diversity and stability of diverse plant communities. Rare-biased frugivore was not latitude specific neither, as both temperate and tropical bird species can show the pattern. We complemented this field study with a field experiment on artificial fruits and found that artificial fruits have greater interaction probabilities with birds when rare in abundance and appearance.

            The project resulted in the collaboration among six research institutions (Penn State University, Carnegie Museum of Natural History, The University of Puerto Rico, Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos, Universidade Estadual Paulista Rio Claro, Universidad Nacional del Comahue, and  Centro de Desarrollo Sustentable in Oxapampa, that involved a total of seven senior researchers. The project resulted in the training of undergraduate students (2), graduate students (4), post docs (1). Training included two master?s students from Penn State fully supported by the project that completed and successfully defended theses, advising on master?s student in Brasil, and one Penn State PhD student partially supported by the project that successfully completed the PhD and produced two high-impact publications. The post-doctoral scholar trained lead the writing and publication of three high-impact publications. Training included the mentoring of one REU student in the USA, and one directing one undergraduate student thesis in Peru.

Additional broader impacts include the offering of one workshop on ?writing and publication?, a  one-week course on basic  ?Design of Ecological Studies and Data Analysis? and an advanced one week course on ?Hierarchical Models and Bayes Analysis?, all offered in Peru to contribute to capacity building. Findings of this project have been presented in national and international conferences that include the Ecological Society of America, the British Ecological Society, Birds Caribbean, Congreso de Biolog?a Peruana, and the Association for tropical Biology and Conservation. In terms of products from this funding, six papers are either published (4) or in press (2), three are ?under review?, and three more are in preparation. The principal database have been submitted to a public data repository (https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.9s4mw6mbq)
